verses.text: Who is like the wise man? And who knows the interpretation of a thing? A man's wisdom makes his face shine, and the hardness of his face is changed.
verses.comment: This verse teaches that wisdom brings true transformation, even affecting one's countenance. The idea of wisdom illuminating the face alludes to the spiritual enlightenment offered by God’s revelation, an Old Testament theme fulfilled in Christ (see John 8:12).

verses.text: I say: Keep the king's command because of God's oath to him.
verses.comment: Obedience to legitimate authority is rooted in faithfulness to God. Referenced by Paul in Romans 13:1, this principle is a call to respect earthly leaders as part of God’s ordained order.

verses.text: Do not be in haste to leave his presence. Do not persist in an evil thing, for he does whatever he pleases.
verses.comment: This verse encourages humility and patience before authority. Spiritually, it points to our approach before God—the true King (Heb. 4:16).

verses.text: For the word of the king is powerful, and who can say to him, 'What are you doing?'
verses.comment: The king’s authority is depicted as unquestionable. This reflects the sovereignty of God, whose decrees cannot be challenged (Dan. 4:35).

verses.text: Whoever keeps a command will know no evil thing, and the wise heart will know the proper time and the just way.
verses.comment: Obedience and discernment are commended. The link to discerning time and way subtly hints at the disciplined life of prayer and moral practice.

verses.text: For there is a proper time and a just way for every matter, though man’s trouble lies heavily upon him.
verses.comment: Reinforces the theme that God has appointed times and seasons. Human burdens must be entrusted to the divine order.

verses.text: For no one knows what will happen, for who can tell him how it will be?
verses.comment: Human limitation before God’s mystery is highlighted. This verse foreshadows man’s need for divine guidance, ultimately fulfilled in Christ’s revelation (John 14:6).

verses.text: No man has power over the spirit to retain the spirit, nor over the day of death. There is no discharge from this war, nor will wickedness deliver those who are given to it.
verses.comment: Death is inevitable, placing all men on equal footing. The language of battle and discharge points toward the inevitability of judgment, a theme deepened throughout Scripture.

verses.text: All this I observed while applying my heart to all that is done under the sun, when man has power over man to his hurt.
verses.comment: Observations about human authority suggest the risk of injustice and oppression, implying the need for accountability and mercy.

verses.text: Then I saw the wicked buried. They used to go in and out of the holy place and were praised in the city where they had done such things. This also is vanity.
verses.comment: Hypocrisy among religious leaders is condemned. The critique of external religion points to the higher standard Jesus calls for (Matt. 23:27-28).

verses.text: Because the sentence against an evil deed is not executed speedily, the hearts of the sons of men are fully set to do evil.
verses.comment: Delayed justice causes greater wickedness. God’s patience is not approval of sin; it is mercy, calling to repentance.

verses.text: Though a sinner does evil a hundred times and prolongs his life, yet surely I know that it will be well with those who fear God, because they fear before him.
verses.comment: Promises ultimate justice and blessing for the faithful. Spiritual reading understands this as pointing to perseverance in faith and hope beyond this life.

verses.text: But it will not be well with the wicked, neither will he prolong his days like a shadow, because he does not fear before God.
verses.comment: Contrasts the fleeting success of the wicked with the lasting hope of those who live in reverence for God. This prepares for the doctrine of judgment and the need for steadfastness.

verses.text: There is a vanity that takes place on earth: there are righteous men to whom it happens according to the deeds of the wicked, and there are wicked people to whom it happens according to the deeds of the righteous. I said that this also is vanity.
verses.comment: The mystery of undeserved suffering is highlighted—a theme addressed by Job and answered in the Cross, where perfect righteousness suffered unjustly (1 Pet. 2:21-24).

verses.text: So I commend joy, for man has nothing better under the sun but to eat and drink and be joyful, for this will go with him in his labor through the days of his life that God gives him under the sun.
verses.comment: The affirmation of holy joy in the midst of life’s mysteries anticipates the Christian idea that daily life, including meals and celebrations, can be sanctified (see 1 Cor. 10:31).

verses.text: When I applied my heart to know wisdom, and to see the business that is done on earth—how neither day nor night do one's eyes see sleep—
verses.comment: The relentless quest for understanding reveals human limits. Faith complements reason, encouraging trust in God’s purposes even when not everything is understood.

verses.text: then I saw all the work of God, that man cannot find out the work that is done under the sun. However much man may toil in seeking, he will not find it out. Even though a wise man claims to know, he cannot find it out.
verses.comment: The limits of wisdom point to the necessity of humble reliance on divine revelation, which the New Testament proclaims is fully revealed in Christ (Col. 2:3).
